body: noticed it was rather slow - - - This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/TokTok/c-toxcore/2560)

comment_data.body: Better yet `-j"$(nproc)"` like other build scripts do.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@ jobs:
       - name: Configure CMake
         run: cmake --preset windows-default
       - name: Build
-        run: cmake --build _build
+        run: cmake --build _build -j4

comment_data.body: Oh, wait, this is Windows. Is this a cmd shell then? I wonder if `%NUMBER_OF_PROCESSORS%` would work in here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@ jobs:
       - name: Configure CMake
         run: cmake --preset windows-default
       - name: Build
-        run: cmake --build _build
+        run: cmake --build _build -j4

comment_data.body: Sounds like it's powershell, so `-j $env:NUMBER_OF_PROCESSORS` then.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@ jobs:
       - name: Configure CMake
         run: cmake --preset windows-default
       - name: Build
-        run: cmake --build _build
+        run: cmake --build _build -j4

comment_data.body: I applied a quick heuristic here of `corecount+2`, similar to what `ninja` does by default.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@ jobs:
       - name: Configure CMake
         run: cmake --preset windows-default
       - name: Build
-        run: cmake --build _build
+        run: cmake --build _build -j4

comment_data.body:
Sure, that's fine. The issue I have is with hard-coding the number of cores the CI system has, so it might change in the future without us noticing. You can add 2 to it, or multiple the number cores by some percentage, etc.

`-j [int]$env:NUMBER_OF_PROCESSORS+2`, with a space between, should do the trick then. That works on my Windows machine. (The cast to int is needed since the env variable is a string, and doing *2 on it would just repeat the string twice instead of treating it as a number and multiplying it).

(I see [Bitcoin also uses `$env:NUMBER_OF_PROCESSORS` in their CI](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/v26.0/.github/workflows/ci.yml#L337), so I expect this to work inside the `run:` of GitHub CI)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@ jobs:
       - name: Configure CMake
         run: cmake --preset windows-default
       - name: Build
-        run: cmake --build _build
+        run: cmake --build _build -j4

@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@ jobs:
       - name: Configure CMake
         run: cmake --preset windows-default
       - name: Build
-        run: cmake --build _build
+        run: cmake --build _build -j4

comment_data.body: Looks like `$([int]$env:NUMBER_OF_PROCESSORS+2)` works. Sorry for the incomplete tip, not very familiar with the powershell.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@ jobs:
       - name: Configure CMake
         run: cmake --preset windows-default
       - name: Build
-        run: cmake --build _build
+        run: cmake --build _build -j4

performed_via_github_app.description:
Codecov provides highly integrated tools to group, merge, archive and compare coverage reports. Whether your team is comparing changes in a pull request or reviewing a single commit, Codecov will improve the code review workflow and quality.

## Code coverage done right.®

1. Upload coverage reports from your CI builds.
2. Codecov merges all builds and languages into one beautiful coherent report.
3. Get commit statuses, pull request comments and coverage overlay via our browser extension.

When Codecov merges your uploads it keeps track of the CI provider (inc. build details) and user specified context, e.g. `#unittest` ~ `#smoketest` or `#oldcode` ~ `#newcode`. You can track the `#unittest` coverage independently of other groups. [Learn more here](
http://docs.codecov.io/docs/flags)

Through **Codecov's Browser Extension** reports overlay directly in GitHub UI to assist in code review in [Chrome](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/codecov/gedikamndpbemklijjkncpnolildpbgo) or Firefox (https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/codecov/)

*Highly detailed* **pull request comments** and *customizable* **commit statuses** will improve your team's workflow and code coverage incrementally.

**File backed configuration** all through the `codecov.yml`. 

## FAQ
- Do you **merge multiple uploads** to the same commit? **Yes**
- Do you **support multiple languages** in the same project? **Yes**
- Can you **group coverage reports** by project and/or test type? **Yes**
- How does **pricing** work? Only paid users can view reports and post statuses/comments.
performed_via_github_app.name: Codecov
